questions.text: What is the correct order of insertion of muscles from near to far from the limbus?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Medial rectus > Inferior rectus

options.label: B
options.text: Medial rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Inferior rectus

options.label: C
options.text: Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: Superior rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Medial rectus

questions.correct_answer: C. Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct insertion order of extraocular muscles from the limbus, following the spiral of Tillaux, is Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus .
  • ➤ Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe pain and swelling around his left eye after a recent accident while playing sports. Upon further inquiry, he reveals that he was struck directly on the eye with a fast-moving object. Considering the mechanism of injury described, which of the following is not typically associated with blowout fractures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ExophthalmosAns. A) Exophthalmos

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exophthalmos is not typically associated with orbital blowout fractures. Common signs and symptoms include diplopia, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and the tear drop sign on imaging studies.

questions.text: Risk factors for primary open-angle glaucoma are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Young age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Young age is not a risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma, while family history, high myopia, and hypertension are.

questions.text: Volume of posterior segment is.

questions.text: A 63-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with sudden onset painful diminution of vision in the left eye. The symptoms began while she was watching a movie in a theatre. On examination, her left eye was congested, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber and mid-dilated, fixed pupil. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute angle closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute angle-closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful loss of vision with redness, corneal haze, a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated, fixed pupil. It is a true ophthalmic emergency requiring immediate treatment to lower intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Schwalbe’s line corresponds to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Descemets membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwalbe’s line is the anatomical landmark that corresponds to the termination of Descemet's membrane in the eye.

questions.text: Which of these statements is true about components of vision 2020?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vision 2020 emphasizes that retinal surgery is performed at the tertiary level , ophthalmia neonatorum is part of childhood blindness , and a primary vision centre serves a population of 50,000 .
  • ➤ retinal surgery is performed at the tertiary level
  • ➤ ophthalmia neonatorum is part of childhood blindness
  • ➤ primary vision centre serves a population of 50,000

questions.text: Which orbital wall is the strongest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lateral

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral orbital wall , composed of the zygomatic bone and the greater wing of the sphenoid , is the strongest orbital wall, providing critical protection to the orbit against lateral trauma.
  • ➤ lateral orbital wall
  • ➤ zygomatic bone and the greater wing of the sphenoid

questions.text: Which of the following is true about MAURICE theory?

options.label: B
options.text: Scattered light is destroyed by mutual interference

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of transparency results if lattice arrangement is altered.

questions.explanation: Ans. D) All the above

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding anterior uveitis is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Iris atrophy in acute anterior uveitis presents with a diffuse pattern.

options.label: B
options.text: Circumcorneal congestion is absent in granulomatous anterior uveitis.

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior synechiae formation is a common complication.

options.label: D
options.text: Busacca nodules are located at the pupillary margin.

questions.correct_answer: C. Posterior synechiae formation is a common complication.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior synechiae formation is a common complication.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior synechiae formation is a hallmark complication of anterior uveitis, leading to significant sequelae if untreated.

questions.text: Identify the instrument depicted and specify the condition it is typically used to assess?

options.label: A
options.text: Luedde Exophthalmometer - used to measure the axial length of the eyeball

options.label: B
options.text: Hertel’s Exophthalmometer - used to measure exophthalmos, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease

options.label: C
options.text: Naugle Exophthalmometer - used for detailed assessments of eye position changes in orbital fractures

options.label: D
options.text: Orbital A-scan - used to measure the orbital tissue thickness in cases of orbital tumors

questions.correct_answer: B. Hertel’s Exophthalmometer - used to measure exophthalmos, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hertel’s Exophthalmometer - used to measure exophthalmos, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease

questions.text: A Myopic patient was posted for Radial Keratotomy. What is the size of the optical zone left while making Peripheral Corneal Incisions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Radial Keratotomy is one of the Surgical Procedures done for correction of Myopia . It is a type of Refractive Keratoplasty which is done to Modify the Refractive Power of the Cornea . In this, Multiple Radial Incisions are made in the periphery of the cornea leaving a Central 4mm Optical Zone . These incisions on Healing cause Flattening of the Corneal Curvature .
  • • Radial Keratotomy is one of the Surgical Procedures done for correction of Myopia .
  • • Surgical Procedures

  • • It is a type of Refractive Keratoplasty which is done to Modify the Refractive Power of the Cornea .

  • • In this, Multiple Radial Incisions are made in the periphery of the cornea leaving a Central 4mm Optical Zone .
  • • Multiple Radial Incisions
  • • periphery
  • • cornea
  • • Central 4mm Optical Zone
  • • These incisions on Healing cause Flattening of the Corneal Curvature .
  • • Healing
  • • Flattening
  • • Corneal
  • • Curvature
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Central Optional Zone in Radial Keratotomy is 4mm.

questions.text: During development of the eyeball, the neural plate becomes thickened & depressed to form which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Optic Sulcus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. The optic vesicle is formed when the neural plate becomes thickened and depressed , leading to the formation of the optic sulcus , which then buds out to form the optic vesicle.
  • • Option B.
  • • optic vesicle
  • • neural plate
  • • thickened
  • • depressed
  • • formation
  • • optic sulcus
  • • Option C. The optic stalk is the structure that connects the developing optic vesicle to the brain . As the optic vesicle grows out to form the eye , the connecting stalk forms the optic nerve .
  • • Option C.
  • • optic stalk
  • • connects
  • • developing optic vesicle
  • • brain
  • • optic vesicle
  • • form
  • • eye
  • • connecting stalk
  • • optic nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understand that during the development of the eyeball , the neural plate becomes thickened and depressed to form the optic sulcus .

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Vogt's triad following an episode of acute primary angle closure glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Glaucomflecken (Anterior Subcapsular Lenticular Opacity). These are the small , white , opaque spots on the lens indicative of previous acute attacks .
  • • Option A. Glaucomflecken
  • • small
  • • white
  • • opaque spots
  • • lens
  • • previous acute attacks
  • • Option B . Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy .
  • • Option B
  • • Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil
  • • sphincter atrophy
  • • Option C. Patches of iris atrophy occurs due to ischemia from the prolonged contact between the iris and the trabecular meshwork .
  • • Option C.
  • • ischemia
  • • prolonged contact
  • • iris
  • • trabecular meshwork

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The components of Vogt's triad for primary angle closure glaucoma include glaukomflecken , iris atrophy , and mid-dilated pupil .
  • ➤ Vogt's triad
  • ➤ primary angle closure glaucoma
  • ➤ glaukomflecken

questions.text: Corneal endothelium receives most of its oxygen supply from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aqueous Humour

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The tear film primarily supplies oxygen to the corneal epithelium (the outermost layer of the cornea), not the endothelium (the innermost layer).
  • • Option A.
  • • oxygen
  • • corneal epithelium
  • • Option B. Atmospheric air is a major source of oxygen for the corneal epithelium when the eye is open. However, the corneal endothelium does not directly access oxygen from the air.
  • • Option B.
  • • major source
  • • oxygen
  • • corneal epithelium
  • • Option D. The vitreous humour is the gel-like substance filling the space between the lens and the retina . It does not play a significant role in supplying oxygen to the corneal endothelium.
  • • Option D.
  • • gel-like substance
  • • lens
  • • retina

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The corneal endothelium, being an avascular layer , primarily receives its oxygen supply from the aqueous humour , which nourishes the inner layers of the cornea .
  • ➤ avascular layer
  • ➤ oxygen
  • ➤ aqueous humour
  • ➤ nourishes
  • ➤ inner layers
  • ➤ cornea
  • ➤ Ref : pg 40/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref : pg 40/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd edition

questions.text: In which type of keratoconjunctivitis are Horner-Tranta-spots observed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vernal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Phlyctenular Keratoconjunctivitis is an allergic , non-infectious type of conjunctivitis , often associated with tuberculosis or staphylococcal infections . It is characterized by the presence of small , whitish-yellow nodules ( phlyctenules ) on the conjunctiva or cornea , but not Horner-Tranta spots.
  • • Option A. Phlyctenular Keratoconjunctivitis
  • • allergic
  • • non-infectious
  • • conjunctivitis
  • • tuberculosis
  • • staphylococcal infections
  • • presence
  • • small
  • • whitish-yellow nodules
  • • phlyctenules
  • • conjunctiva
  • • cornea
  • • Option C. Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis is a highly contagious viral conjunctivitis , caused by adenovirus , particularly serotypes 8 , 19 , and 37 . Symptoms include watery discharge , red eye , and photophobia . Follicles on the conjunctiva , not Horner-Tranta spots, are a characteristic finding .
  • • Option C. Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis
  • • highly contagious viral conjunctivitis
  • • adenovirus
  • • serotypes 8
  • • 19
  • • 37
  • • watery discharge
  • • red eye
  • • photophobia
  • • Follicles
  • • conjunctiva
  • • characteristic finding
  • • Common clinical manifestations of Epidemic Kerato-Conjunctivitis (EKC).
  • • Epidemic Kerato-Conjunctivitis (EKC).
  • • Photomicrograph of the inferior conjunctival fornix of a patient with acute EKC , showing lymphoid follicles and subconjunctival hemorrhage . Photomicrograph of an eye with corneal subepithelial infiltrates ( white arrows ).
  • • Photomicrograph of the inferior conjunctival fornix of a patient with acute EKC , showing lymphoid follicles and subconjunctival hemorrhage .
  • • Photomicrograph of the inferior conjunctival fornix of a patient with acute EKC , showing lymphoid follicles and subconjunctival hemorrhage .
  • • Photomicrograph
  • • inferior conjunctival fornix
  • • acute EKC
  • • lymphoid follicles
  • • subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • • Photomicrograph of an eye with corneal subepithelial infiltrates ( white arrows ).
  • • Photomicrograph of an eye with corneal subepithelial infiltrates ( white arrows ).
  • • eye
  • • corneal subepithelial infiltrates
  • • white arrows
  • • Option D. Trachoma, Caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis , this chronic infectious disease leads to conjunctival scarring , entropion , trichiasis , and potentially blindness . It does not feature Horner-Tranta spots but rather follicles and scarring on the conjunctiva.
  • • Option D. Trachoma,
  • • bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis
  • • chronic infectious disease
  • • conjunctival scarring
  • • entropion
  • • trichiasis
  • • potentially blindness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Horner-Tranta spots , which are characteristic of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis , are small , white dots at the limbus caused by aggregates of eosinophils and epithelial cells , differentiating it from other forms of keratoconjunctivitis .

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of sudden decrease in vision in left eye and pain with movement of eye. On examination, the pupil showed RAPD in left eye and colour vision assessment revealed a red-green deficit. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Optic neuritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Papilledema:
  • • Option B
  • • Papilledema:
  • • Description: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure . It usually affects both eyes. Relevance to Case: While papilledema can cause visual symptoms, it does not typically present with sudden vision loss or pain with eye movement. RAPD is not a characteristic finding in papilledema.
  • • Description: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure . It usually affects both eyes.
  • • Description: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure . It usually affects both eyes.
  • • Description:
  • • swelling of the optic disc
  • • increased intracranial pressure
  • • Relevance to Case: While papilledema can cause visual symptoms, it does not typically present with sudden vision loss or pain with eye movement. RAPD is not a characteristic finding in papilledema.
  • • Relevance to Case: While papilledema can cause visual symptoms, it does not typically present with sudden vision loss or pain with eye movement. RAPD is not a characteristic finding in papilledema.
  • • Relevance to Case:
  • • does not typically present with sudden vision loss
  • • Option C. Retinal Detachment:
  • • Option C. Retinal Detachment:
  • • Description: Retinal detachment involves the separation of the neurosensoryretina from its Retinal Pigment Epithelium. Symptoms include floaters, flashes of light, and a "curtain" over part of the field of vision. Relevance to Case: The sudden decrease in vision could suggest retinal detachment , but the pain with eye movement and RAPD are not typical features of this condition. Also, retinal detachment does not usually affect color vision.
  • • Description: Retinal detachment involves the separation of the neurosensoryretina from its Retinal Pigment Epithelium. Symptoms include floaters, flashes of light, and a "curtain" over part of the field of vision.
  • • Description: Retinal detachment involves the separation of the neurosensoryretina from its Retinal Pigment Epithelium. Symptoms include floaters, flashes of light, and a "curtain" over part of the field of vision.
  • • Description:
  • • separation of the neurosensoryretina
  • • Retinal Pigment Epithelium.
  • • Relevance to Case: The sudden decrease in vision could suggest retinal detachment , but the pain with eye movement and RAPD are not typical features of this condition. Also, retinal detachment does not usually affect color vision.
  • • Relevance to Case: The sudden decrease in vision could suggest retinal detachment , but the pain with eye movement and RAPD are not typical features of this condition. Also, retinal detachment does not usually affect color vision.
  • • Relevance to Case:
  • • sudden decrease in vision
  • • retinal detachment
  • • pain with eye movement and RAPD are not typical features
  • • Option D. CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion):
  • • Option D. CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion):
  • • Description: CRAO is an occlusion of the central retinal artery leading to acute, painless vision loss in one eye. Relevance to Case: The sudden loss of vision is consistent with CRAO, but the presence of pain with eye movement is not typical associated with CRAO.
  • • Description: CRAO is an occlusion of the central retinal artery leading to acute, painless vision loss in one eye.
  • • Description: CRAO is an occlusion of the central retinal artery leading to acute, painless vision loss in one eye.
  • • Description:
  • • occlusion of the central retinal artery
  • • acute, painless vision loss
  • • Relevance to Case: The sudden loss of vision is consistent with CRAO, but the presence of pain with eye movement is not typical associated with CRAO.
  • • Relevance to Case: The sudden loss of vision is consistent with CRAO, but the presence of pain with eye movement is not typical associated with CRAO.
  • • Relevance to Case:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden decrease in vision, pain with movement of the eye , RAPD , and a red-green color vision deficit are classic signs of Optic Neuritis . MRI is the imaging modality of choice and treatment is pulse IV Methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by oral corticosteroids.
  • ➤ decrease in vision, pain with movement of the eye
  • ➤ RAPD
  • ➤ red-green color vision deficit are classic signs of Optic Neuritis
  • ➤ REF : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 314
  • ➤ REF : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 314

questions.text: Ocriplasmin is used in treatment of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitreomacular Traction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Diabetic Macular Edema (DME) is a complication of Diabetes characterized by Intraretinal Fluid Accumulation due to Microleakage from capillaries . Treatments for DME typically involve Anti-VEGF Injections, Corticosteroids , and Laser Therapy .
  • • Option A
  • • Diabetes
  • • Intraretinal Fluid Accumulation
  • • Microleakage
  • • capillaries
  • • Anti-VEGF Injections, Corticosteroids
  • • Laser Therapy
  • • Option B . Keratoconus is a Degenerative Disorder of the Cornea characterised by thinning and Ectasia which cause the Cornea to become Conical in shape . Treatment options for keratoconus include corneal cross-linking , custom soft contact lenses , and corneal transplant in advanced cases.
  • • Option B
  • • Degenerative Disorder
  • • Cornea
  • • thinning
  • • Ectasia
  • • Cornea
  • • become Conical
  • • shape
  • • keratoconus
  • • corneal cross-linking
  • • custom soft contact lenses
  • • corneal transplant
  • • Option D . The primary treatments for Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG) are medications that reduce intraocular pressure , laser therapy , and surgical procedures .
  • • Option D
  • • Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG)
  • • medications
  • • reduce intraocular pressure
  • • laser therapy
  • • surgical procedures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ocriplasmin is primarily used in the treatment of Vitreomacular Traction (VMT) . It works by enzymatically dissolving the proteins that cause the vitreous to adhere to the macula , thus relieving the traction that can impair vision .
  • ➤ treatment
  • ➤ Vitreomacular Traction (VMT)
  • ➤ enzymatically dissolving
  • ➤ proteins
  • ➤ cause
  • ➤ vitreous
  • ➤ adhere
  • ➤ macula
  • ➤ relieving
  • ➤ traction
  • ➤ can impair vision
  • ➤ Ref: KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 597
  • ➤ Ref: KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 597

questions.text: Circulus arteriosus major is seen in which part of the eye?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Root of iris

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pupillary Margin : it is the outer edge of the pupil . The pupillary ruff is the anterior termination of the posterior pigmented layer of the iris .
  • • Option A.
  • • Pupillary Margin
  • • outer edge of the pupil
  • • pupillary ruff is the anterior termination
  • • posterior pigmented layer of the iris
  • • Option B. Collarette : The iris is divided into a pupillary zone and a ciliary zone by a circular ridge , located 1.5mm away from the pupillary margin , called the collarette.
  • • Option B.
  • • Collarette
  • • iris is divided into a pupillary zone
  • • ciliary zone by a circular ridge
  • • 1.5mm away from the pupillary margin
  • • collarette.
  • • IRIS CRYPTS : The anterior limiting layer lines the iris and is the anterior-most condensation of the iris stroma. It is absent in the areas of crypts.
  • • IRIS CRYPTS
  • • Option D. Limbus : The limbus of the eye is the junction of the cornea and the sclera .
  • • Option D.
  • • Limbus
  • • eye is the junction of the cornea and the sclera
  • • Functions of Limbus:
  • • Transition Zone : The limbus acts as a transition zone between the transparent cornea and the opaque sclera. This border is necessary for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the eye. Stem Cell Reservoir : The limbus contains stem cells that are crucial for the regeneration and repair of corneal tissue. These limbal stem cells continuously replenish the corneal epithelium. Barrier Function : It serves as a barrier to prevent the conjunctival epithelial cells from migrating onto the corneal surface, which is important for preserving corneal clarity and vision. Nutrient and Waste Exchange : The limbus plays a role in the exchange of nutrients and waste materials between the cornea and the conjunctiva. This is vital for maintaining the health of the corneal cells. Vascular Supply : Although the cornea is avascular (lacking blood vessels) for transparency, the limbus contains blood vessels that supply nutrients to the peripheral cornea and aid in immune responses. Anatomical Markings : Clinically, the limbus is used as a landmark for various eye surgeries and procedures due to its distinct anatomical positioning.
  • • Transition Zone : The limbus acts as a transition zone between the transparent cornea and the opaque sclera. This border is necessary for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the eye.
  • • Transition Zone : The limbus acts as a transition zone between the transparent cornea and the opaque sclera. This border is necessary for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the eye.
  • • Transition Zone
  • • Stem Cell Reservoir : The limbus contains stem cells that are crucial for the regeneration and repair of corneal tissue. These limbal stem cells continuously replenish the corneal epithelium.
  • • Stem Cell Reservoir : The limbus contains stem cells that are crucial for the regeneration and repair of corneal tissue. These limbal stem cells continuously replenish the corneal epithelium.
  • • Stem Cell Reservoir
  • • Barrier Function : It serves as a barrier to prevent the conjunctival epithelial cells from migrating onto the corneal surface, which is important for preserving corneal clarity and vision.
  • • Barrier Function : It serves as a barrier to prevent the conjunctival epithelial cells from migrating onto the corneal surface, which is important for preserving corneal clarity and vision.
  • • Barrier Function
  • • Nutrient and Waste Exchange : The limbus plays a role in the exchange of nutrients and waste materials between the cornea and the conjunctiva. This is vital for maintaining the health of the corneal cells.
  • • Nutrient and Waste Exchange : The limbus plays a role in the exchange of nutrients and waste materials between the cornea and the conjunctiva. This is vital for maintaining the health of the corneal cells.
  • • Nutrient and Waste Exchange
  • • Vascular Supply : Although the cornea is avascular (lacking blood vessels) for transparency, the limbus contains blood vessels that supply nutrients to the peripheral cornea and aid in immune responses.
  • • Vascular Supply : Although the cornea is avascular (lacking blood vessels) for transparency, the limbus contains blood vessels that supply nutrients to the peripheral cornea and aid in immune responses.
  • • Vascular Supply
  • • Anatomical Markings : Clinically, the limbus is used as a landmark for various eye surgeries and procedures due to its distinct anatomical positioning.
  • • Anatomical Markings : Clinically, the limbus is used as a landmark for various eye surgeries and procedures due to its distinct anatomical positioning.
  • • Anatomical Markings
  • • The health and integrity of the limbus are essential for corneal health and overall visual acuity. Damage or disease affecting the limbal region can lead to serious ocular conditions, such as limbal stem cell deficiency, which can impair vision.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The blood supply of the iris and the anterior segment of the eye is derived from the circulus arteriosus major which is formed by the anastomoses of the long posterior ciliary and anterior ciliary arteries.
  • ➤ blood supply of the iris and the anterior segment of the eye
  • ➤ circulus arteriosus major
  • ➤ formed by the anastomoses of the long posterior ciliary
  • ➤ anterior ciliary arteries.
  • ➤ Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22 nd edition
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Parson’s diseases of the eye 22 nd edition

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Muller’s muscle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Superior Rectus : This muscle, responsible for elevating the eye , is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III), not by sympathetic nerves.
  • • Option A.
  • • Superior Rectus
  • • responsible for elevating the eye
  • • innervated by the oculomotor nerve
  • • Option B. Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS) : The LPS raises the upper eyelid and is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve . It is not supplied by sympathetic nerves.
  • • Option B.
  • • Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS)
  • • raises the upper eyelid
  • • innervated by the oculomotor nerve
  • • Optiion C. Medial Rectus : This muscle, which moves the eye medially (towards the nose), is innervated by the oculomotor nerve as well . It does not receive sympathetic innervation.
  • • Optiion C.
  • • Medial Rectus
  • • moves the eye medially
  • • innervated by the oculomotor nerve as well

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is Müller’s Muscle , a smooth muscle in the upper eyelid that aids in eyelid elevation.
  • ➤ extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is Müller’s Muscle
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which is the thickest wall of the orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral wall

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Medial Wall : The medial wall of the orbit is one of the thinnest and most fragile parts . It is formed primarily by the ethmoid bone and partly by the lacrimal bone , the frontal bone , and the lesser wing of the sphenoid. This wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells , making it prone to injury and subsequent communication with the nasal cavity.
  • • Option A
  • • Medial Wall
  • • medial wall of the orbit
  • • thinnest and most fragile parts
  • • formed primarily by the ethmoid bone
  • • lacrimal bone
  • • frontal bone
  • • lesser wing of the sphenoid.
  • • wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells
  • • Option C . Roof : The roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate of the frontal bone and, to a lesser extent , by the lesser wing of the sphenoid . It separates the orbital contents from the anterior cranial fossa and provides protection from superior impacts . It's relatively thin compared to the lateral wall but stronger than the medial wall.
  • • Option C
  • • Roof
  • • roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate
  • • frontal bone
  • • lesser extent
  • • lesser wing of the sphenoid
  • • separates the orbital
  • • anterior cranial fossa
  • • provides protection from superior impacts
  • • Option D . Floor : The floor of the orbit is formed by the orbital surface of the maxillary bone , along with small contributions from the zygomatic bone and the palatine bone . This wall is thin and vulnerable to fractures , especially from trauma to the orbit, as it separates the orbital contents from the maxillary sinus.
  • • Option D
  • • Floor
  • • formed by the orbital surface
  • • maxillary bone
  • • small contributions
  • • zygomatic bone
  • • palatine bone
  • • wall is thin
  • • vulnerable to fractures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit , providing substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts , and distinguishing itself in strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall , the moderately strong roof , and the thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit .
  • ➤ lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit
  • ➤ substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts
  • ➤ strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall
  • ➤ moderately strong roof
  • ➤ thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit
  • ➤ Ref : pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Anita, a 32-year-old female patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of persistent tearing since several months and occasional eye discharge in her left eye. She notices that her left eye frequently waters, especially when she is outdoors or exposed to windy conditions. She has no history of eye trauma or previous eye surgeries. The ophthalmologist suspects a nasolacrimal duct obstruction in the left eye. What is the normal length of the duct involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 12 to 18 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 5 to 10 mm : This length is of the body of the lacrimal sac .
  • • Option A.
  • • 5 to 10 mm
  • • length is of the body
  • • lacrimal sac
  • • Option B. 20 to 25 mm : This is the length of the inferior meatus .
  • • Option B.
  • • 20 to 25 mm
  • • length of the inferior meatus
  • • Option D. 1 to 2 mm: This is the length of the vertical part of the canaliculus .
  • • Option D.
  • • 1 to 2 mm:
  • • length of the vertical part of the canaliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal length of the nasolacrimal duct , which drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity , is approximately 12 to 18 mm
  • ➤ normal length
  • ➤ nasolacrimal duct
  • ➤ drains tears from the lacrimal sac
  • ➤ nasal cavity
  • ➤ 12 to 18 mm
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What is the function of an Eye Bank?

options.label: B
options.text: Evaluate and distribute eye tissue for transplantation

options.label: C
options.text: Use donor eyes for research and education

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Promotion of eye donation. Registration & collection of donated eyes. Receiving & preservation of donor eyes. Distribution & research activities.

  • • Registration & collection of donated eyes.

  • • Receiving & preservation of donor eyes.
  • • Receiving
  • • preservation
  • • Distribution & research activities.
  • • Distribution & research activities.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the ophthalmology clinic with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) in the right eye. An MRI of the orbit reveals a mass, and a biopsy is performed. The histopathology slide is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Retinoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma is characterized histologically by small round cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei and Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) in a child is a key clinical sign that warrants investigation for retinoblastoma. Histopathology is crucial for diagnosing ocular tumors and differentiating between various types.
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma is characterized histologically by small round cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei and Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma
  • ➤ Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) in a child is a key clinical sign that warrants investigation for retinoblastoma.
  • ➤ Leukocoria
  • ➤ Histopathology is crucial for diagnosing ocular tumors and differentiating between various types.
  • ➤ Histopathology

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents with gradual, progressive visual field loss in both eyes. Examination reveals increased intraocular pressure, cupping of the optic disc, and visual field testing shows arcuate scotoma. Which cell type in the retina is primarily affected in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ganglion cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Glaucomatous optic atrophy primarily affects retinal ganglion cells, leading to their apoptosis and resulting in progressive optic nerve changes and visual field defects.
  • ➤ Glaucomatous optic atrophy primarily affects retinal ganglion cells, leading to their apoptosis and resulting in progressive optic nerve changes and visual field defects.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of an infant with PHPV?

options.label: A
options.text: PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.

options.label: B
options.text: PHPV is frequently associated with Down syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior PHPV generally has a poor prognosis due to the high likelihood of amblyopia.

options.label: D
options.text: Calcification is a common finding in PHPV and should be expected in this case.

questions.correct_answer: A. PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a non-hereditary, congenital anomaly due to the failure of the fetal hyaloid artery to regress, often presenting unilaterally with leukocoria, and is associated with a good prognosis when anterior without calcification.
  • ➤ Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a non-hereditary, congenital anomaly due to the failure of the fetal hyaloid artery to regress, often presenting unilaterally with leukocoria, and is associated with a good prognosis when anterior without calcification.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmologist's office complaining of blurred vision particularly when looking at horizontal lines. On examination, she is diagnosed with "against-the-rule" astigmatism. Which of the following prescriptions is most appropriate to correct her visual problem?

options.label: C
options.text: +2.5 diopters sphere and +1.25 diopters cylinder at 90 degrees

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) -1.25 diopters cylinder at 90 degrees

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For against-the-rule astigmatism, where the horizontal curvature is predominant, a cylindrical correction oriented at 90 degrees is typically required. The amount of correction should match the degree of astigmatism as determined by an eye examination.
  • ➤ For against-the-rule astigmatism, where the horizontal curvature is predominant, a cylindrical correction oriented at 90 degrees is typically required.
  • ➤ The amount of correction should match the degree of astigmatism as determined by an eye examination.

questions.text: Based on the provided image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dermoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ocular dermoids, characterized by their distinct, tissue-composed appearance not normally present in that area, can cause visual disturbances such as astigmatism if they press against the cornea. Identification and appropriate management are essential for maintaining ocular health and comfort.
  • ➤ Ocular dermoids, characterized by their distinct, tissue-composed appearance not normally present in that area, can cause visual disturbances such as astigmatism if they press against the cornea.
  • ➤ Identification and appropriate management are essential for maintaining ocular health and comfort.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a recent onset of drooping eyelid on one side, and on examination, he is diagnosed with Horner's syndrome. What is the most appropriate surgical intervention for the ptosis observed in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fasanella-Servat operation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of Horner's syndrome with mild ptosis, the Fasanella-Servat operation offers a suitable surgical option, utilizing the patient's existing levator function for minimal but effective correction. This is generally reserved for patients with mild ptosis and good levator function, avoiding more extensive surgical procedures unless necessary
  • ➤ In cases of Horner's syndrome with mild ptosis, the Fasanella-Servat operation offers a suitable surgical option, utilizing the patient's existing levator function for minimal but effective correction.
  • ➤ This is generally reserved for patients with mild ptosis and good levator function, avoiding more extensive surgical procedures unless necessary
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Causes of Acquired Ptosis
  • ➤ Causes of Acquired Ptosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with visual disturbances. Upon retinal examination, the ophthalmologist notes the presence of Roth spots. Which condition is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.
  • ➤ Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.
  • ➤ Roth's spots may be seen in -
  • ➤ Roth's spots may be seen in -
  • ➤ Leukemia Diabetes Subacute bacterial endocarditis Hypertensive retinopathy HIV retinopathy Systemic lupus erythematosus Anemia Pre-eclampsia Anoxia
  • ➤ Leukemia
  • ➤ Diabetes
  • ➤ Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • ➤ Hypertensive retinopathy
  • ➤ HIV retinopathy
  • ➤ Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • ➤ Anemia
  • ➤ Pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ Anoxia

questions.text: Based on the provided image, identify the specific surgical step being illustrated in Image A.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Capsulorrhexis is a foundational step in modern cataract surgery, setting the stage for the safe removal of the lens and implantation of an IOL, ensuring better outcomes for patients undergoing cataract extraction.
  • ➤ Capsulorrhexis is a foundational step in modern cataract surgery, setting the stage for the safe removal of the lens and implantation of an IOL, ensuring better outcomes for patients undergoing cataract extraction.

questions.text: Which of the following test is not used to assess color vision?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Amsler's grid test

questions.text: A child with history of malnutrition is examined and the following finding is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Anterior staphyloma

questions.text: An ophthalmologist is selecting a gonioscope for a procedure to examine a patient's anterior chamber angle for signs of glaucoma. Which of the following gonioscopes should the ophthalmologist choose as they are classified as indirect?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Examples

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with refractory glaucoma has been recommended for a surgical intervention to manage his intraocular pressure, as medications have not been effective. His ophthalmologist suggests a procedure involving the implantation of a glaucoma valve. Which of the following surgeries typically involves this type of implant?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glaucoma valve implants (setons) are used in specific surgical settings to manage severe or refractory glaucoma by providing a controlled pathway for fluid drainage, helping to sustain lower intraocular pressure and prevent further optic nerve damage
  • ➤ Glaucoma valve implants (setons) are used in specific surgical settings to manage severe or refractory glaucoma by providing a controlled pathway for fluid drainage, helping to sustain lower intraocular pressure and prevent further optic nerve damage

questions.text: After collecting a vitreous sample from a patient during the evening, you need to instruct the lab staff on the best way to store the sample overnight before analysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate storage method?

options.label: A
options.text: The sample should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius

options.label: B
options.text: The sample should be incubated at 37 degrees Celsius

options.label: C
options.text: The sample should be kept in the deep freezer

options.label: D
options.text: The sample should be refrigerated for the initial 3 hours and then incubated

questions.correct_answer: A. The sample should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Correct storage conditions are essential for the preservation of biological samples. For vitreous samples intended for short-term analysis, maintaining a consistent refrigeration temperature of 4 degrees Celsius is generally the best practice to ensure sample integrity and reliability of subsequent laboratory tests.
  • ➤ Correct storage conditions are essential for the preservation of biological samples.
  • ➤ For vitreous samples intended for short-term analysis, maintaining a consistent refrigeration temperature of 4 degrees Celsius is generally the best practice to ensure sample integrity and reliability of subsequent laboratory tests.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given image: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orbital cellulitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital cellulitis is characterized by painful swelling, lid edema, chemosis, and restricted, painful ocular movements. It is often caused by the spread of infection from adjacent sinuses and requires prompt treatment with systemic antimicrobials to prevent serious complications such as cavernous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects will be seen in a patient with anterior pituitary tumor causing pressure over optic chiasma?( FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bitemporal hemianopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The visual pathway and various lesions along the pathway are summarized in the following diagram

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old man who experienced eye pain, photophobia, and redness for the past 2 days after injuring his eye by brushing it against leaves and thorns while gardening? (FMGE June 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fungal keratitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fungal keratitis is commonly associated with trauma from vegetative matter. Key clinical features include a dry corneal ulcer with feathery edges, satellite lesions, and a possible immune ring. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with sudden painless loss of vision. Examination reveals perception of only hand movements in the affected eye with afferent pupillary defect. On examination, his fundus was pale in color with a red spot in the center. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CRAO

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differential diagnosis of cherry red spot:
  • ➤ Differential diagnosis of cherry red spot:
  • ➤ CRAO Trauma Niemann pick disease Gaucher’s disease Tay sach’s disease Sandhoff’s disease
  • ➤ CRAO
  • ➤ Trauma
  • ➤ Niemann pick disease
  • ➤ Gaucher’s disease
  • ➤ Tay sach’s disease
  • ➤ Sandhoff’s disease

questions.text: The Koeppe nodules is seen in: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koeppe nodules are located at the pupillary margin of the iris and are associated with both granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

questions.text: During an ophthalmic examination, the patient is asked to direct her gaze to her right side. During this ocular movement, the right lateral rectus muscle is being used. Which of the following is its yoke muscle?( FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left medial rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles from opposite eyes that work together to direct the gaze in a specific direction. For rightward gaze, the yoke muscles are the right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus.

questions.text: A patient working in an iron factory presents with visual disturbance and is found to have iron deposits in the eye. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this ocular finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Siderosis bulbi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Siderosis bulbi is caused by iron deposits in the eye, commonly seen in patients with a history of iron foreign body exposure, leading to significant ocular changes and potential blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following type of cataract is seen in ocular blunt trauma?( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rosette cataract is commonly seen in ocular blunt trauma.

questions.text: The type of cataract associated with blunt trauma is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rosette cataract is the type of cataract that develops following blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by its distinctive flower-like pattern.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia gravis
  • ➤ Myasthenia gravis
  • ➤ A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane. The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages. Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features. A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation. The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.
  • ➤ A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • ➤ The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • ➤ Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • ➤ A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • ➤ The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography
  • ➤ The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography? ( AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia. This increases on extroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.
